content: Solar Eclipse 2015: How to watch a solar eclipse safely

tag: html body div div section section div div div div span time span
html body div div section section div div div div span time span
html body div div section section div div div div div span
html body div div section section div div div div div span
html body div div section div section div div div div div div div figure div div div div div span
content: To enjoy the CBBC Newsround website at its best you will need to have JavaScript turned on.

tag: html body div div section div section div div div div div div div figure figcaption span
content: Will you be able to see the solar eclipse?

tag: html body div div section div section div div div h2 span
html body div div section div section div div div p span
content: A solar eclipse occurs when the Moon's orbit lines up in between the Sun and the Earth.

tag: html body div div section div section div div div p span
content: The Moon blocks out the Sun's light for a short time, casting a shadow on the Earth.

tag: html body div div section div section div div div p span
content: It's a rare event and only possible when the Moon is at exactly the right distance from the Earth.

tag: html body div div section div section div div div div div div div figure div div div div div span
content: To enjoy the CBBC Newsround website at its best you will need to have JavaScript turned on.

tag: html body div div section div section div div div div div div div figure figcaption span
content: Hayley finds out how to watch the solar eclipse safely

tag: html body div div section div section div div div p b span
html body div div section div section div div div p a span
content: How will you watch the eclipse?

tag: html body div div section div section div div div div div div div figure div div div div div span
content: To enjoy the CBBC Newsround website at its best you will need to have JavaScript turned on.

tag: html body div div section div section div div div div div div div figure figcaption span
html body div div section div section div div div h2 span
content: When can I see an eclipse in the UK?

tag: html body div div section div section div div div p span
content: On Friday 20 March the UK will experience the first eclipse of 2015.

tag: html body div div section div section div div div p span
content: It will be a partial eclipse, so the sky will darken but the Sun will still peek out from behind the Moon.

tag: html body div div section div section div div div div div div div div div div div span
content: People living in the north of the UK will see more of the Sun covered

tag: html body div div section div section div div div p b span
html body div div section div section div div div p span
content: - the eclipse will begin in the UK

tag: html body div div section div section div div div p b span
html body div div section div section div div div p span
content: - the Moon will be nearest the middle of the Sun

tag: html body div div section div section div div div p b span
html body div div section div section div div div p span
content: - daylight is restored and the eclipse is over

tag: html body div div section div section div div div h2 span
html body div div section div section div div div p span
content: "In 1999, when there was the last major eclipse, no-one really had smartphones or took selfies," said Daniel Hardiman-McCartney, an eye expert from the College of Optometrists.

tag: html body div div section div section div div div p span
content: "This could potentially be very dangerous because people might be tempted to look at the Sun as they try to get the perfect shot or clip."

tag: html body div div section div section div div div p a span
html body div div section div section div div div h2 span
html body div div section div section div div div ul li b span
content: Never look directly at the Sun: you can damage your eyes forever.

tag: html body div div section div section div div div ul li span
content: Even the small amount of Sun peeking out from behind the Moon during an eclipse is enough to make you go blind.

tag: html body div div section div section div div div ul li span
content: Never look at the Sun through binoculars or a telescope.

tag: html body div div section div section div div div ul li span
content: Don't look directly at the Sun through sunglasses, or exposed photographic film - they will not protect your eyes.

tag: html body div div section div section div div div h2 span
content: How can I safely watch the eclipse?

tag: html body div div section div section div div div div div div div div div div div span
html body div div section div section div div div div div div div div div div div span
content: Special eclipse viewing specs provide a safe way to watch the eclipse...

tag: html body div div section div section div div div div div div div div div div div span
html body div div section div section div div div div div div div div div div div span
content: ...but the safest option is to watch the eclipse broadcast on live TV.

tag: html body div div section div section div div div h2 span
content: How to make a pinhole camera

tag: html body div div section div section div div div p span
content: Another way to safely enjoy the eclipse is to make a pinhole camera. This will project an image of the eclipse onto card.

tag: html body div div section div section div div div p span
content: You'll need two pieces of card. Make a small hole in the centre one of them - no more than 4mm across.

tag: html body div div section div section div div div p span
content: Tilt the card with the hole towards the Sun and use it to project an image of the eclipse onto the other card.

tag: html body div div section div section div div div div div div div div div div div span
html body div div section div section div div div div div div div div div div div span
content: Pinhole cameras should only be used with your back to the Sun

tag: html body div div section div section div div div h2 span
content: When is the next eclipse in the UK?

tag: html body div div section div section div div div p span
content: The next big partial eclipse in the UK will be in August 2026.

tag: html body div div section div section div div div p span
content: The UK hasn't seen a total solar eclipse - where the Moon completely covers the Sun - since 1999, and won't get another one until 2090.
